messageBody:
## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Weekly Space Weather Summary Report for September 19, 2018 - September 25, 2018
##
## Message Issue Date: 2018-09-26T21:50:48Z
## Report Coverage Begin Date: 2018-09-19T00:00Z
## Report Coverage End Date: 2018-09-25T23:59Z
## Message ID: 20180926-7D-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Solar activity was at low levels during this reporting period. There were no significant flares or CMEs.      

Geomagnetic activity was at minor levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <=5 for the reporting period. The highest value of Kp=5 occurred during the synoptic periods of 2018-09-21T21:00Z - 2018-09-22T03:00Z. This slight increase in geomagnetic activity was associated with the arrival of a coronal hole high speed stream detected by DSCOVR/ACE at L1 around 2018-09-21. Solar wind speed reached values of ~550 km/s on 2018-09-22.

STEREO A IMPACT/PLASTIC instruments also detected the arrival of a coronal hole high speed stream around 2018-09-20. Solar wind speed reached values of ~450 km/s on 2018-09-22.  

The >0.8 MeV energetic electron flux in the Earth's outer radiation belt was significantly elevated, around 70-80% of the threshold level of 10^5 pfu most of the entire reporting period. These significantly elevated energetic electron fluxes in the Earth's outer radiation belt detected by GOES 13 were associated with two coronal hole high speed streams that were detected by DSCOVR/ACE at L1 around 2018-09-17 and the one detected around 2018-09-21, respectively (see notifications 20180919-AL-001, 20180921-AL-001 and 20180923-AL-001).

The energetic proton flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES and the 13-100 MeV protons at STEREO A were all at background levels for the entire reporting period. 

Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been low to moderate this week due to energetic electron fluxes on the Earth's outer radiation belt described above. 

##Events:
Flares (M-class and above)
Date         Start     Stop      Peak      Class   Location         
None Observed  

CMEs (>500 km/s):

Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
None Observed  

Non-Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
None Observed  

## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2018-09-26T00:00Z 
## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2018-10-02T23:59Z

Solar activity is expected to be low for the upcoming week. There are only a couple of decayed active regions present on the visible solar surface that could produce some flare and CME activity. Geomagnetic activity is also expected to be low for the upcoming week.

## Notes: 
SCORE CME typification system:
S-type: CMEs with speeds less than 500 km/s
C-type: Common 500-999 km/s
O-type: Occasional 1000-1999 km/s
R-type: Rare 2000-2999 km/s
ER-type: Extremely Rare >3000 km/s
http://swc.gsfc.nasa.gov/main/score


NASA Community Coordinated Modeling Center/Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC, http://swrc.gsfc.nasa.gov ) Disclaimer

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Space Weather Notification - Continued Radiation Belt Enhancement
##
## Message Issue Date: 2018-09-23T23:30:42Z
## Message ID: 20180923-AL-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

This is an update to the notifications with IDs 20180917-AL-001, 20180919-AL-001, and 20180921-AL-001. Significantly elevated energetic electron fluxes in the Earth's outer radiation belt. GOES 13 "greater than 0.8 MeV" integral electron flux first exceeded the threshold of 10^5 pfu starting at 2018-09-17T19:10Z. The electron flux continues to be elevated between 70% - 80% of the threshold, currently at 77,600 pfu.

The elevated energetic electron flux levels are caused by the high speed stream starting at 2018-09-17T00:49Z and the high speed stream starting at 2018-09-21T14:18Z.

NASA spacecraft at GEO, MEO and other orbits passing through or in the vicinity of the Earth's outer radiation belt can be impacted.

Activity ID: 2018-09-23T16:20:00-RBE-001. 

## Notes:

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Space Weather Notification - Continued Radiation Belt Enhancement
##
## Message Issue Date: 2018-09-21T23:55:38Z
## Message ID: 20180921-AL-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

This is an update to the notifications with IDs 20180917-AL-001 and 20180919-AL-001. Significantly elevated energetic electron fluxes continue in the Earth's outer radiation belt. GOES 13 "greater than 0.8 MeV" integral electron flux first exceeded the threshold of 10^5 pfu starting at 2018-09-17T19:10Z. Throughout the last two days, the electron flux has been below this threshold, but has remained elevated near 70% - 80% of the threshold.

The elevated energetic electron flux levels are caused by the high speed stream starting at 2018-09-10T09:47Z and the high speed stream starting at 2018-09-17T00:49Z.

NASA spacecraft at GEO, MEO and other orbits passing through or in the vicinity of the Earth's outer radiation belt can be impacted.

Activity ID: 2018-09-17T19:10:00-RBE-001. 

## Notes:

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Weekly Space Weather Summary Report for September 12, 2018 - September 18, 2018
##
## Message Issue Date: 2018-09-19T21:08:16Z
## Report Coverage Begin Date: 2018-09-12T00:00Z
## Report Coverage End Date: 2018-09-18T23:59Z
## Message ID: 20180919-7D-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:


Solar activity was at low levels during this reporting period. There were no significant flares or CMEs.  


Geomagnetic activity was at minor levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <=5 for the reporting period. The highest value of Kp=5 occurred during the synoptic period of 2018-08-14T00:00Z-03:00Z. This slight increase in geomagnetic activity was associated with the arrival of a coronal hole high speed stream detected by DSCOVR/ACE at L1 around 2018-09-10. Solar wind speed reached values of >600 km/s on 2018-09-15.
Another coronal hole high speed stream was detected by DSCOVR/ACE at L1 around 2018-09-17, solar wind speed reached values of 500-550 km/s on 2018-09-17 and 2018-09-18.


The >0.8 MeV energetic electron flux in the Earth's outer radiation belt crossed the threshold level of 10^5 pfu starting at 2018-09-13T23:40Z and continued to be elevated until the end of the reporting period. These significantly elevated energetic electron fluxes in the Earth's outer radiation belt detected by GOES 13 were associated with two coronal hole high speed streams, one on 2018-09-10 and one on 2018-09-17 described above (see notifications 20180913-AL-001, 20180914-AL-001, 20180915-AL-001 and 20180917-AL-001).


The energetic proton flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES and the 13-100 MeV protons at STEREO A were all at background levels for the entire reporting period. 


Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been low to moderate this week due to energetic electron fluxes on the Earth's outer radiation belt described above. 



##Events:
Flares (M-class and above)
Date         Start     Stop      Peak      Class   Location         
None Observed  


CMEs (>500 km/s):

Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
None Observed  

Non-Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
None Observed  

## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2018-09-19T00:00Z 
## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2018-09-25T23:59Z


Solar activity is expected to be low for the upcoming week. There are only small and decayed active regions present on the solar surface that could produce some flare and CME activity. Geomagnetic activity is expected to be low to moderate for the upcoming week due to the expected arrival of a coronal hole high speed stream around 2018-09-22.  


## Notes: 
SCORE CME typification system:
S-type: CMEs with speeds less than 500 km/s
C-type: Common 500-999 km/s
O-type: Occasional 1000-1999 km/s
R-type: Rare 2000-2999 km/s
ER-type: Extremely Rare >3000 km/s
http://swc.gsfc.nasa.gov/main/score

##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

This is an update to the notifications with IDs 20180914-AL-001 and 20180915-AL-001. Significantly elevated energetic electron fluxes in the Earth's outer radiation belt. GOES 13 "greater than 0.8 MeV" integral electron flux first exceeded the threshold of 10^5 pfu starting at 2018-09-13T23:40Z. The electron flux continued to cross the threshold, with the latest crossing at 2018-09-17T19:10Z.

The elevated energetic electron flux levels are caused by the high speed streams starting at 2018-09-10T09:47Z and 2018-09-17T00:49Z.

NASA spacecraft at GEO, MEO and other orbits passing through or in the vicinity of the Earth's outer radiation belt can be impacted.

Activity ID: 2018-09-13T23:40:00-RBE-001.

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Weekly Space Weather Summary Report for September 05, 2018 - September 11, 2018
##
## Message Issue Date: 2018-09-12T20:18:45Z
## Report Coverage Begin Date: 2018-09-05T00:00Z
## Report Coverage End Date: 2018-09-11T23:59Z
## Message ID: 20180912-7D-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:


Solar activity was at low levels during this reporting period. There were no significant flares or CMEs.    
  

Geomagnetic activity was at moderate levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <=6 for the reporting period. The highest value of Kp=6 occurred during the synoptic periods of 2018-09-11T06:00Z-12:00Z (see notifications 20180911-AL-001 and 20180911-AL-002). This moderate increase in geomagnetic activity was associated with a coronal hole high speed stream detected by DSCOVR/ACE at L1 around 2018-09-10. Solar wind speed reached values of ~570 km/s starting on 2018-09-11. 
Another coronal hole high speed stream was detected by DSCOVR/ACE at L1 around 2018-09-07, solar wind speed reached values around 500 km/s on 2018-09-07.  

STEREO A IMPACT/PLASTIC instruments detected the arrival of a coronal hole high speed stream around 2018-09-08. Solar wind speed reached values of ~600 km/s on 2018-09-08.


The > 0.8 MeV energetic electron flux detected at GOES remained below the threshold level of 10^5 pfu for the entire reporting period. 


The energetic proton flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES and the 13-100 MeV protons at STEREO A were all at background levels for the entire reporting period. 


Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been low this week.



##Events:
Flares (M-class and above)
Date         Start     Stop      Peak      Class   Location         
None Observed  


CMEs (>500 km/s):

Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
None Observed 

Non-Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
None Observed   

## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2018-09-12T00:00Z 
## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2018-09-18T23:59Z


Solar activity is expected to be low for the upcoming week. There are a few small or decayed active regions present on the solar disk that have some potential for flare or CME activity. Geomagnetic activity is expected to be low to moderate for the upcoming week due to the expected arrival of a coronal hole high speed stream around 2018-09-17. The greater than 0.8 MeV energetic electron flux at the Earth's outer radiation belt detected by GOES 13 could cross the threshold of 10^5 pfu around 2018-09-12 due to the coronal hole high speed stream described above.  


## Notes: 
SCORE CME typification system:
S-type: CMEs with speeds less than 500 km/s
C-type: Common 500-999 km/s
O-type: Occasional 1000-1999 km/s
R-type: Rare 2000-2999 km/s
ER-type: Extremely Rare >3000 km/s
http://swc.gsfc.nasa.gov/main/score

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Space Weather Notification - Geomagnetic Storm
##
## Message Issue Date: 2018-09-11T13:03:03Z
## Message ID: 20180911-AL-002
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Intensifying space weather storm in the Earth's magnetosphere. Geomagnetic Kp index has reached level 6 (moderate) for the synoptic periods 2018-09-11T06:00Z to 2018-09-11T09:00Z and 2018-09-11T09:00Z to 2018-09-11T12:00Z.

The storm is caused by high speed stream starting at 2018-09-10T09:47Z.

NASA spacecraft at GEO, MEO, polar and other orbits passing through or in the vicinity of the Earth's ring current and auroral regions can be impacted.

Activity ID: 2018-09-11T06:00:00-GST-001.

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Weekly Space Weather Summary Report for August 29, 2018 - September 04, 2018
##
## Message Issue Date: 2018-09-05T18:29:10Z
## Report Coverage Begin Date: 2018-08-29T00:00Z
## Report Coverage End Date: 2018-09-04T23:59Z
## Message ID: 20180905-7D-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

 
Solar activity was at low levels during this reporting period. There were no significant flares or CMEs.    

Geomagnetic activity was at below minor levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <=3 for the reporting period. 

STEREO A IMPACT/PLASTIC instruments detected the arrival of coronal hole high speed streams around 2018-08-29 and 2018-09-02. Solar wind speed reached values of ~550 km/s on 2018-08-30 and ~600 km/s on 2018-09-03, respectively.

The > 0.8 MeV energetic electron flux in the Earth's outer radiation belt was elevated above the threshold level of 10^5 pfu at the beginning of the reporting period on 2018-08-29 and remained elevated throughout the reporting period until 2018-09-04. These significantly elevated energetic electron fluxes in the Earth's outer radiation belt detected by GOES 13 were associated to the combination of the S-type CME and coronal hole high speed stream arrival detected by DSCOVR/ACE at L1 on 2018-08-25 and 2018-08-26, respectively (see notifications 20180830-AL-001, 20180901-AL-001 and 20180903-AL-001).  

The energetic proton flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES and the 13-100 MeV protons at STEREO A were all at background levels for the entire reporting period. 

Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been low to moderate this week due to energetic electron fluxes on the Earth's outer radiation belt described above.  

##Events:
Flares (M-class and above)
Date         Start     Stop      Peak      Class   Location         
None Observed  

CMEs (>500 km/s):

Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
None Observed  

Non-Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
None Observed  

## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2018-09-05T00:00Z 
## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2018-09-11T23:59Z

The solar activity is expected to be low to moderate for the upcoming week.  There are two active regions present on the solar surface that could produce some flare and CME activity. Geomagnetic activity is expected to be low to moderate for the upcoming week due to the possible arrival of a few coronal hole high speed streams around 2018-09-06 and 2018-09-10.

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Space Weather Notification - Continued Radiation Belt Enhancement
##
## Message Issue Date: 2018-09-03T22:36:25Z
## Message ID: 20180903-AL-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

This is an update to the notifications with IDs 20180826-AL-004, 20180828-AL-001, 20180830-AL-001, and 20180901-AL-001.

Energetic electron fluxes in the Earth's outer radiation belt continue to be significantly elevated. GOES 13 "greater than 0.8 MeV" integral electron flux first exceeded 10^5 pfu starting at 2018-08-26T18:40Z. The electron flux continues to be elevated, with the latest threshold crossing at 2018-09-02T21:00Z, and remains elevated although below the threshold today.

The elevated energetic electron flux levels are caused by the high speed stream with ID 2018-08-26T07:00:00-HSS-001.

NASA spacecraft at GEO, MEO and other orbits passing through or in the vicinity of the Earth's outer radiation belt can be impacted.

Activity ID: 2018-08-26T18:40:00-RBE-001. 

## Notes:
